title: Using Frame of Reference Theory to Understand the Self-concept of Academically Able Students
abstract: According t o the frame of reference theory (Marsh, 1986), students make both internal ability comparisons across academic areas and external ability comparisons relative t o peers when determining academic selfconcept. Understanding the processes utilized by high-ability students t o formulate their academic self-concept is an important consideration in meeting the educational needs of this population. To determine the applicability o f the frame o f reference theory, verbal and mathematics self-concept and achievement measures were administered t o 103 academically able high school students. Consistent w i t h theoretical findings with students in the general population, path analysis verified the dual influence of both internal and external processes on student self-concepts. Self-concept has long been thought an important variable to understand relative to educational programs, particularly specialized programs for gifted students (Kolloff & Feldhusen, 1984). A realistic and healthy conception of self has been identified as crucial to the realization of potential for gifted students (Whitmore, 1980) and an important objective of educators of gifted children (Feldhusen, 1986). Although many researchers have documented self-concept of gifted students as positively advantaged over their nongifted peers (Coleman & Fults, 1982; Kames & Wherry, 1981; Kelly & Colangelo, 1985), the relationship of specific academic self-concept to achievement in specific content areas is unclear. Research to determine the relationship between self-concept and academic achievement for the gifted student has often been conducted by assessing a general academic or scholastic self-concept (e.g.

abstract.text: According t o the frame of reference theory (Marsh, 1986), students make both internal ability comparisons across academic areas and external ability comparisons relative t o peers when determining academic selfconcept. Understanding the processes utilized by high-ability students t o formulate their academic self-concept is an important consideration in meeting the educational needs of this population. To determine the applicability o f the frame o f reference theory, verbal and mathematics self-concept and achievement measures were administered t o 103 academically able high school students. Consistent w i t h theoretical findings with students in the general population, path analysis verified the dual influence of both internal and external processes on student self-concepts. Self-concept has long been thought an important variable to understand relative to educational programs, particularly specialized programs for gifted students (Kolloff & Feldhusen, 1984). A realistic and healthy conception of self has been identified as crucial to the realization of potential for gifted students (Whitmore, 1980) and an important objective of educators of gifted children (Feldhusen, 1986). Although many researchers have documented self-concept of gifted students as positively advantaged over their nongifted peers (Coleman & Fults, 1982; Kames & Wherry, 1981; Kelly & Colangelo, 1985), the relationship of specific academic self-concept to achievement in specific content areas is unclear. Research to determine the relationship between self-concept and academic achievement for the gifted student has often been conducted by assessing a general academic or scholastic self-concept (e.g.

body_text.text: 1989). Differentiated from social, behavioral, physical, or other domains of self-concept, academic self-concept is the belief one has about one's general ability relative to school performance. The overall association of academic self-concept to academic achievement appears to make intuitive sense: the better one thinks one can do in school, the better one performs. On the other hand, current research with gifted students (e.g., Van Boxtel & Monks, 1992) indicates that multidimensional self-concept models (see Byme & Shavelson, 1986; Marsh & Shavelson, 1985) are necessary in differentiating the effects of achievement on self-concept. Recent findings demonstrate distinct cognitive differences between students who are gifted in mathematics and students who are gifted in verbal areas (Benbow & Minor, 19901 and these findings lend support for further differentiating academic self-concept into verbal and mathematic areas for able learners.

Explored analytically within the context of student perceptions of ability in specific subject areas, the association between achievement and self-concept does not appear to be straightforward (Hoge & Renzulli, 1993) . For example, Marsh (1986) found that self-concept in one academic subject may not be related to achievement in other areas. He formulated a "frame of reference', theory to explain such findings. The purpose of this study was to assess the applicability of the frame of reference theory with academically able students placed in honors classes.

Proponents of the internal/external frame of reference theory (e.g., Marsh, 1986; Marsh, Byme, & Shavelson, 1988) believe that student academic self-concepts are determined in relation to both internal and external comparisons or frames of reference. According to this theory, students concurrently compare both their individual academic achievements across subject areas (internal comparisons) and their ability level relative to others within their learning environment (external comparisons). For example, an internal comparison is the perception that one's performance is better in mathematics than language; thus, this student exhibits higher mathematics self-concept. An external comparison refers to the belief that one's mathematics performance is better than other students in the mathematics class; subsequently, this student reports high mathematics self -concept. The theoretical model depicted in Figure 1 was developed to explain the frame of reference theory (Marsh, 1986) . The model predicts a substantial positive correlation between verbal and mathematics achievement and is based upon well-documented reports in the literature. Strong positive direct effects for both verbal achievement on verbal self-concept and for mathematics achievement on mathematics self-concept are predicted. These expected effects are due to the external comparison process on student verbal and mathematics selfconcepts. The model also posits a weak negative direct effect of verbal achievement on mAthematics self-concept and mathematics achievement on verbal self-concept due to the internal comparison process. In support of the strong positive-weak negative predicted pattern of effects, research has found achievement in specific academic areas to be more highly correlated with self-concept in matching areas than in other areas (Marsh & Shavelson, 1985) . Finally, because students theoretically combine both external (positive effects) and internal (negative effects) processes, the relationship between verbal and mathematics self-concepts is specified to be approximately zero.

The frame of reference theory conceptualizes the nature of the comparisons made by students in formulating their academic self-concepts in relation to performance. Students are believed to be influenced both by the internal comparison of performance across academic areas and the external comparison of performance relative to other students within their frame of reference (or particular learning environment). Although the internal/external process posited in the frame of reference theory has been supported through research using average-ability students, the model has apparently not been examined with high-ability students. Marsh (1986) has called for furthering the generalizability of the theory through research with varied instruments and different subject groups.

The sample included students who were primarily (98%) ninthgraders, 13-15 years of age, and attending honors courses in a suburban public schooI. Six percent of those invited to participate either declined or provided incomplete data and thus were not included in the analyses. The final sample (N = 103; 49 male, 54 female) was approximately 94% of the originally targeted sample. The students were enrolled in one of the five sections of science honors classes taught by one instructor at one of two high schools within the school district. The majority of the participants were white, middleto upper-middle-class students nominated by parents or teachers for placement in the honors science program. All students participated in at least two honors courses during their academic year. High achievement scores (85th percentile) in any area could be used as support for program placement, but those scores were not the sole criterion and therefore some variance in achievement was to be expected. The program expanded the regular academic curriculum in science to include greater abstraction and complexity, critical thinking, and problem solving within the context of experimentation and discussion.

All students voluntarily completed a self-report instrument during their honors physical science class. Students were asked to complete the instruments for a study designed to determine how students "feel about themselves at school." The questionnaire contained two counterbalanced components that measured verbal and mathematics self-concept. In addition, gender and achievement test scores (Iowa Tests of Basic Skills [ITBS], 1986) were obtained for each student from school records.The ITBS scores (Level 14-Form G) used in this study included both standardized language total (containing measures of spelling, capitalization, punctuation, usage, and expression) and mathematics total (consisting of concepts, problems, and computation). Language scores ranged from 23 to 99; the mathematics scores ranged from 32 to 99. Student achievement test scores are routinely provided to parents; therefore, students may have had an awareness of their ITBS scores.

The ME: Self-concept Scale for Gifted Children is a self-report questionnaire used to assess a student's perception of general academic self-concept (Feldhusen & Kolloff, 198 1) . This instrument was specifically developed to assess the perceptions of academically able children concerning their academic abilities, strengths, and talents. The ME self-concept scale is considered to be a reliable and valid research measure of the general academic self-concept of bright students (Feldhusen, Sayler, Nielsen, & Kolloff, 1990) .

The 40-item ME scale was adapted for use in the current study to allow for an assessment of self-concept in the language-and mathematics-content domains. Five of the original ME items cited abilities unrelated to either the language or mathematics areas. Such items as "I can draw well" were deleted from the questionnaire because they were unrelated to the content areas of interest. All items were then altered to direct the student's attention to mathematics and then to language or English. For example, the statement "I am smart" became "I am smart in English" or "I am smart in Math." "I do well on tests" became "I do well on Math tests" and "I do well on English" tests. Students responded to the final 35-item, domain-specific self-concept scales by either agreeing or disagreeing with each statement. Possible scores ranged from 0-35, with one point given for each item of agreement. Thus, higher scores indicated higher perceived languageherbal or mathematics self-concept. Coefficient alpha estimates calculated on the student sample for each modified self-concept scale revealed good internal consistency reliabilities (verbal = .854j mathematics = .855).

The theoretical linkage presumed to exist among the variables is graphically presented in Figure 1 . (See Table 1 for descriptive statis- tics.) This model was tested with conventional path analysis, which is used to estimate model parameters via a series of multiple regressions (Pedhazur, 1982) . Figure 2 contains the estimated path coefficients (standardized regression coefficients) presented along the unidirectional arrows. The relative size of each coefficient is indicative of that variable's predictive importance in the model. Additionally, when a path coefficient is squared, this value represents the percentage of explained variance for each path. Bivariate correlations between the achievement and self-concept variables in the model are given in parentheses on the diagram. As predicted, a strong positive correlation was obtained between verbal and mathematics achievement; about 49% of the variance was shared, and verbal and mathematics self-concepts were not significantly related (r = .0295). Significant positive effects of verbal achievement were anticipated and achieved on verbal self-concept, and significant positive effects of mathematics achievement were anticipated and achieved on mathematics self-concept (support for an external frame of reference). Whereas, verbal achievement had a significant negative effect on mathematics self-concept, mathematics achievement had a low negative effect on verbal self-concept (support for an internal frame of reference). Thus, the pattern of the results in the path analysis shown in Figure 2 indicates that the theory withstood the statistical test and was not disconfirmed. The lack of correlation between the self-concept dimensions suggests that the academically able students used both internal and external frames of reference in determining their academic self-concepts.

Similar to previous studies with the general population (see Marsh, 1990 ) and with the population of students who are gifted (see Van , 1992) , the present study supports the importance of examining academic self-concept using multiple dimensions. Together with support in the literature for two distinct types of giftedness (e.g., Benbow & Minor, 1990) , the pattern differences found herein between verbal and mathematics self-concepts indicates the importance of specific-area considerations.

Consistent with the frame of reference theory, the low or near-zero correlation of verbal to mathematics self-concept indicates that highability students indeed use both internal and external references in formulating perceptions of academic self. The current study reveals that achievement in mathematics and verbal areas are highly correlated, whereas academic self-concepts are not. Interpreted in light of the theoretical model presented in Figure 1 , this means that perceptions of differential ability in mathematics or verbal areas (internal) and perceptions of ability differences relative to others in the class (external) appears to affect the formulation of academic self-concept for the students in the study. However, the coefficients represent-ing the internal comparison processes are negative as hypothesized, but they are not of the same magnitude. The negative path from verbal achievement to mathematic self-concept reaches statistical significance while the path from mathematics achievement to verbal self-concept does not. This pattern of results replicates findings with the general population currently being reported elsewhere (Skaaivik & Rankin, 1990; Tay, Licht, Tate, & Simpson, 1994) . Although both self-concepts appear to be influenced by internal and external processes, verbal self-concept is more influenced by external and less influenced by internal processes than is mathematics self-concept. In other words, for two able learners with similar achievement in mathematics, the student with the lower verbal achievement tends to exhibit higher mathematics self-concept. On the other hand, given similar verbal achievement, those with lower mathematics achievement do not necessarily report higher verbal self-concept.

Caution must be exercised in broadly interpreting these results for all populations of able learners. The reader is reminded that the sample in this study was a group of students identified for differentiated honors courses based on high achievement in any academic area. Further study with students identified as academically talented primarily in verbal or mathematic areas would provide additional evidence of the differential profiles found in the present study. Additionally, although this study tested a model in which achievement directly affected self-concept, the results presented here do not exclude other dynamic models where the self-concept to achievement relation is reciprocal or where other variables may influence academic self-concept.

In conclusion, it seems imperative to examine the pattern of selfconcept to achievement relationships with homogeneously grouped students across multiple academic areas. The results presented here suggest that a portion of the ability perceptions of academically able students may be influenced by comparisons made both across academic areas and relative to other peer-group students.
